comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content:
Hey Diego -

I have a few thoughts here, and I'll also see if I can get some folks with more industry experience than me to weigh in.

(1) To me, it sure sounds like the chef made an assumption based on the color of your skin that you didn't speak English. That's obnoxious. It is true that there are certainly a lot of non-English speaking dishwashers in the industry, but that had to feel crappy when you've made a conscious choice to try and work your way up from the dishroom and the first thing you face is that kind of assumption.

(2) It is entirely common in the industry for facilities not to be optimized to make jobs as efficient as they could be. I think it is fine to make a suggestion, but on the other hand if it is your first day or two in a professional kitchen, it might be the case that you need to just work with what is available for now. And especially, this is a restaurant that is literally brand new, they probably aren't thinking the dish system is their biggest problem right now. 

(3) Even though it might seem like the dishpit isn't a real high skill position, there is still a lot of knowledge and speed that comes with time on the job, so it is kind of a crappy situation for you to be in there on your own, with  no-one experienced to show you the ropes.

(4) To me it is shortsighted of that manager, if you are offering to come in an hour early and get things organized, to say no to that kind of initiative.

Bottom line - my guess is that if you've decided to try and work your way up from dishwasher, you'll have to make a call as to whether that can happen in this kitchen or not. But actually I think you'd be better off asking to stage somewhere better, working as an extra hand for free on prep and garde mange and get in the door that way.

comments.author: dana
comments.content:
Diego- I am a professional pastry chef, working 14 hours a day, which is probably about 6 less than anyone in a managerial position who is opening a restaurant. I barely had the time/patience to read your lenghtey comment. Don't take this as an insult. But this industry moves FAST, and the higher up you get, the less time you have for details like the racks in a dish pit. The best dishwashers out there come in, blow through your dishes without speaking, finish, and go home. Strike that. They go to a second job somewhere. You're jumping in with grand intentions, but into a position where the standard has been set by people who work like maniacs, don't ask questions, and always get their job done.  

If you are feeling injured on your second day by your bosses attitude, maybe this isn't the right way for you to enter the industry. Take it as a lesson, the dishwasher is the most overworked, thankless job in an industry filled with overworked thankless jobs. 

I've been through restauarant openings. It's not just that there's no system for the dishes yet, there's not a system for anything, and the dish pit is low on the priority list, behind how to get the food cooked, and how to get it to the customer. 

If the interaction you described made you feel injured, you either need a big lesson in sucking it up, (this is not being mean, this is absolutely necessary for a career in restaurants) or you need a more gentle introduction to the industry. You're going to be that chef someday, who only needs to know one thing. You have dishes, they need to get done between the hours of 4 and 12, and you need someone to do it. It won't be personal, it's a yes or no question. Will they do it for you or won't they. 

Either put your head down, learn to work with what you have, and stick it out, using it as practice for the years of grueling thankless overworked underaccommodated hours you are about to endure as a line cook, OR go get a slower more delicate start by offering your unskilled hands for free as a stage. You will likely find that about 1000 times more satisfying. But the same lesson applies, keep your head down, push through, and work with what they give you. 

You are a culinary student. you don't have to scrub yourself out of the dish pit into a prep cook job if you don't want to. You have educated yourself and have other ways into kitchens.

comments.author: chris
comments.content:
Thank you so much for this article. it confirmed a lot of the assumptions i had about work in a professional kitchen and let me know what to expect - which is exactly what i needed.

i'm going to be staging for a michelin star restaurant on wednesday starting at noon. i've been working on my own techniques nightly working as a grocery clerk in order to hopefully get my foot in the door. i ended up inside this restaurant (on my 30 min lunch break, on advice from a coworker) i knew nothing about, inquiring about a dishwashing position i learned they had already filled.

 i knew i just wanted to get into the kitchen somehow. within 30 seconds i had both head chefs in front of me asking me questions, such as if i had chefs shoes and pants and good knives. they said they needed someone to work garde (i had to ask them what that meant).

my previous identity was a d1 athlete, but i always knew i wanted to cook. however, i have absolutely no formal training. the past 4 days have been a blur. i bought the founding chef's book, replaced my inherited 30-yr-old 8" wusthof with a new one, and even treated my roommate to a $120 dinner just to get an idea of the place. 

 i am really excited about the team aspect of being in kitchen. i am trying to prepare myself the best i can so i do not miss this opportunity. however, while i have total confidence in my work ethic, ability to learn, and social skills, i am beside myself with some weird sort of calm anxiety. 

obviously, this can lead to a career as a professional chef. ive always thought about culinary school, but what most excites me about this opportunity is the idea that i can skip all of that formal training, as long as i can make the cut. is this an accurate expectation? i have no illusions about the life of a cook. i want to feel like i am contributing to something greater than myself, even at the grocery store. that drives me to always find ways to improve the store. i hope these skills translate. 

anyways, this opportunity is way above my league. and you have helped me tremendously in preparation. how nervous should i be, given my confidence in work ethic and learning ability? and even without formal training, can I take this further? how long would i have to work to be qualified for another position in a professional kitchen?

comments.author: John
comments.content:
Hi Michael,
     I made a comment here before on 6/30/14.  I just wanted to let you know that I started a PT internship last weekend!  My schedule is weekends and one weeknight.  I am very excited about this because I never worked in a professional kitchen before plus I don't have to quit my job.  I am an avid cook at home though and really work on perfecting every dish I make.  I seem to be convinced that cooking is something that I can do for the rest of my life.  But I am sort of testing the waters via this gig just in case I may be wrong :-).  
     Anyway, I really think the first day was the hardest part because I had no clue what I was getting myself into.  My biggest worry was whether I would be able to stay standing for several hours and not my basic kitchen skills and knowledge or lack thereof.  
     So what have I learned? (0) First, let me describe how I got the internship.  I went to one of the restaurants on my favorite restaurant list (between 3-4 pm) and filled out an application.  I asked to talk to the chef but he was in a meeting for a while so I just said that I was going to come back.  I didn't go back :-) but instead wrote a very carefully written honest email to the restaurant.  I got an interview, followed up after over a week, and was told to come in to start the internship :-) (1) Things happen really fast so listen carefully and ask for clarification if it's not clear to you when you are given instructions. (2) It's true what they say that there are many Spanish speaking people who work BOH :-) They work really quickly!  But they were also very nice and helpful.  One of them helped me a lot when the Chef was busy.  (3)  Being nice and helpful to everyone around you can do wonders! (4)  Working hard can do wonders! (4) The first day is the most difficult for the body.  If you are like me who has a regular job sitting down working in front of a computer, then working in a professional kitchen will shock your body!  And this is even though I work out at the gym and play sports regularly!  I had to take a painkiller pill before going to bed :-( The second day, my body was fine :-) (5) Now I know what the sharpie is for - labeling prepped food that is put in storage or later use!  (6) Crocs Bistro Clogs are great!  (7) Work fast but carefully.
       These are just some of my initial thoughts after only 2 days of working so some of them may change in time :-)  I'm already looking forward to the next time I'll be at the restaurant!
       Btw, thanks again for all your very helpful thoughts and insights on staging.  I'm also thankful to everyone who made comments especially Nico from The Fit Duck.  I read all (!) his blog entries and it helped me gain some rather interesting insights about working in BOH.  I also appreciate his effective use of emoticons :-).
       Again, thanks!  I'll be stopping by here again sometime to report about my future experiences :-).

comments.author: Beemah
comments.content:
Great article!  

Much like many people in the industry, I got my start through the "School of hard knocks."  If your goal is to find yourself your first kitchen job, I would also add that you should never underestimate the power of a good, honest, "Sir, I don't know much, but I've got decent knife skills, and I'm happy to learn anything you'll teach me."  

This is how I landed my first prep job in a long-standing fine dining restaurant, and spent a few years, leaving as a sous chef, to learn more about pastry.  That job, too, was a "Sir, I don't know anything about pastry, but I'll gladly chop vegetables and prep for you, if you'll only let me hang out in the pastry department in my off time to learn more."  

I suppose I got lucky with a couple of chefs who were willing to take a chance on an eager 24 year old who was willing to put himself out there. 

What I like best about your article is that it's more than just a description on how to get a good stage, it's also a great list of hints on how to start your first kitchen experience, paid or not.  Some chefs use the stage as an interview tool, and others are happy to just let someone come in and hang out (read:  work hard) for awhile to learn.  Whatever your goal, these are excellent pointers to aspiring young chefs!

But no matter how tired I am or how hard the day is, I find myself smiling from ear to ear as I get in my car to go home. I never thought I could be so happy at a job & it's so satisfying on so many levels. Anyway, this really is great advice. I'm going to keep reading what you recommended b/c, like you said, it's inspiring & always interesting to hear what the more experienced have to offer. Thank you for such a thoughtful, well-written & helpful post!!

comments.author: Jeanne
comments.content: thank you so much for taking the time to write such an informative article.  I am a fairly accomplished home chef and as a hobby I arrange food and wine pairing parties for 30 to 50 people where i do most of the recipe development and the cooking.  At my last party the executive chef of a well regarded local restaurant attended one of my dinners as the guest of one of my regulars. I was very nervous having a real chef at my table, and to my surprise he asked me to do a pop up with him. When I told him I had no restaurant experience, he asked me to stage at his place.  Subsequently another guest who is a food photographer introduced me to two of his clients, one of whom is well connected to Thomas Keller.  Both of these clients suggested we do a pop up together in the near future.  It's like a dream come true but I am also terrified at the prospect because I have no professional experience.  What in your opinion are the top things you would recommend I learn to successfully maneuver the pop up experience? I know how to cook but have no experience dealing with the fast pace of a typical service and maneuvering through the various roles in a commercial kitchen. How many weeks (months?) do you think an appropriate stage would take for me to learn these things?

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: That's great, they must think highly of your food to be interested in doing a popup with you. I would say that if you are already preparing and cooking for 30-50 people, that basically is a popup! So you are well on your way. I'd take that opportunity to stage, preferably for a week more. Other than that, the key to a popup is really the same as any other restaurant situation: preparation. Make those lists, check them and check them again, do everything you possibly can in advance, work clean, pack up all the prep really neatly, make sure you have everything you need for chilling, heating, finishing, serving. Make sure you have all the help you need for final cooking, service and cleanup. Just be incredibly organized so that you aren't improvising when it is time to serve, and it should all go great.
